title: Anvil Debug Traces are in Incorrect Order
body:
### Component

Anvil

### Have you ensured that all of these are up to date?

- [X] Foundry
- [X] Foundryup

### What version of Foundry are you on?

forge 0.2.0 (15204ec 2022-11-29T00:07:45.954046141Z)

### What command(s) is the bug in?

anvil --steps-tracing

### Operating System

Linux

### Describe the bug

The debug traces returned by anvil have an incorrect order. They do not contain the EVM instructions in the order that they were executed. Example is shown below as Example Trace. Note that the trace first contains all the "depth: 1" instructions and then all the "depth: 2" instructions even though they should be interleaved like: "depth: 1", "depth: 2", "depth: 1".

To reproduce, do the following steps:

1. `forge init`
2. Put attached `A.sol` in `src`
3. Put attached `A.s.sol` in `script`
4. Put `PRIVATE_KEY=0xac0974bec39a17e36ba4a6b4d238ff944bacb478cbed5efcae784d7bf4f2ff80` in `.env`
5. Run `anvil --steps-tracing`
6. Run `forge script -f http://127.0.0.1:8545 script/A.s.sol:AScript --broadcast --sender 0xf39fd6e51aad88f6f4ce6ab8827279cfffb92266`

If you point me to where the bug might be I am also happy to try to fix it and submit a pull request.

Example Trace:
```json
{

  "id": 1,

    "gas": 48482,

```

A.sol
```
// SPDX-License-Identifier: UNLICENSED
pragma solidity ^0.8.13;

contract A {
    uint256 public number;
    B public b;
    uint x;

    constructor() {
        b = new B();
    }

    function test() public {
        b.f();
        x = 1;
    }
}


contract B {

    function f() public pure returns(uint){
        return 42;
    }
}
```

A.s.sol
```
// SPDX-License-Identifier: UNLICENSED
pragma solidity ^0.8.13;

import "forge-std/Script.sol";
import "src/A.sol";

contract AScript is Script {
    A a;

    function setUp() public {
    }

    function run() external {
        uint256 deployerPrivateKey = vm.envUint("PRIVATE_KEY");
        vm.startBroadcast(deployerPrivateKey);
        a = new A();
        a.test();
        vm.stopBroadcast();

    }
}
```

thanks for flagging

the traces are constructed here

https://github.com/foundry-rs/foundry/blob/965ebee5017dcf76a3a0783e05b18266a9e6e8f9/evm/src/trace/mod.rs#L99

but perhaps this bug is during recording:

https://github.com/foundry-rs/foundry/blob/965ebee5017dcf76a3a0783e05b18266a9e6e8f9/evm/src/trace/mod.rs#L47

cc @shekhirin

Thanks for the pointer @mattsse. I proposed a fix. As described in #3793 the problem (based on my understanding) is how the traces are being combined into one big trace. Happy to receive more feedback.
Seems fixed as the PR #3793 has been merged.
@ritzdorf curious if anyone from your side would be keen on implementing js tracing like geth for anvil. We can provide guidance etc if you guys need the feature cc @samczsun

Hi @gakonst ,

that is a good question. Honestly, I didn't really consider it. We will first use the geth-style tracing (which we definitely plan to use). 

About that. We found another bug. This: https://github.com/foundry-rs/foundry/blob/965ebee5017dcf76a3a0783e05b18266a9e6e8f9/evm/src/executor/inspector/tracer.rs#L139 can sometimes underflow and crash anvil, looks like an revm bug to me, where the `self.gas_inspector.borrow().gas_remaining()` grows without a depth change. However, I only had limited time to check so far, will provide more info tomorrow.

TL;DR: Thanks a lot for the offer. We don't plan for js tracing immediately, but will get back to you once we do. (The item where we would need it is pretty far down on the to-do list.)
Got it - makes total sense. We'll look at the revm bug, most helpful would be a repro issue on the revm repo so we can triage quickly
